title: Crocker School Solution Could Cost $50M-$60M
maintext:
FITCHBURG -- The city has issued a request for proposals for a feasibility study that will develop potential designs and related costs associated with either building an addition, renovating the existing, or constructing an entirely new building at Crocker Elementary School.
Colliers International has been hired to manage the project at Crocker school, said Assistant Superintendent of Finance and Operations Robert Jokela. It’s the same company performing a similar service for the City Hall renovation project.
According to the request for proposals, which closes on Oct. 24, the estimated total cost of the project could be between $50,000,000 and $60,000,000.
The Massachusetts School Building Authority has agreed to reimburse the city for 80 percent of eligible costs related to the feasibility study and construction, according to Jokela.
On Oct. 3, interested designers will take a walk through Crocker Elementary School before compiling bids, he said.
According to Jokela, on Feb. 6 the City Council signed off on a $1 million loan order to finance the feasibility study and project management services from Colliers International.
The MSBA is expected to reimburse the city for the feasibility study and project management services in the amount of $800,000, he said.
In other school building needs, the City Council as a Whole is set to take up an additional appropriation of $400,000 for Fitchburg Public Schools at its Tuesday, Oct. 9 meeting.
The appropriation is required in order for the city to meet its net school spending requirement under the state’s Chapter 70 funding formula.
While the School Committee will ultimately vote on how the district will use the funds, Jokela said he will recommend the bulk of it go toward school building needs.
His recommendation will be to spend about $250,000 of the net school spending money on mold remediation at Fitchburg High School, which like school buildings in other districts experienced an outbreak over the summer after a string of humid days.
Jokela will propose spending another $50,000 of the net school spending money paying the deductible on an insurance claim related to cleaning up after a fire broke out in fish tank in a science room at the high school.
The School Committee may vote to pledge the remaining $100,000 to social-emotional programming and student needs, he said.
But Jokela said a chance remains that the entire appropriation could be put toward building needs.
